This startup missed out big time, with the team ending up in routine corporate jobs at routine companies. It was ahead of the curve by several years and could have been a big tech company of the day.

1121206762168668160.text:
But that team had grasped the below would be a thing, in 2003-2004:
* beautiful online local maps
* presence pages for local businesses
* reviews of local businesses by other people
* local advertising 
* local search
* friend of friends networkpic.twitter.com/UjVnMqfwWz

1121206761237598209.text: The venture collapsed though as it was trying to solve a two-sided marketplace problem at the same time: it needed users, and based on those users it needed to sell ad space on these local websites to local businesses. The community of users didn't materialize, and it shut down.

1121206760327368704.text: We had a ranking of local favorite restaurants, and these were also plotted on our custom map which someone could click on. People could submit ratings and reviews, which others could see. This was live in 2003 while Yelp launched in 2004.

1121206759442399232.text: It was a job I was very proud of at the time since I got it over a top student who also wanted it. Except it paid nothing. The founders were spending their capital on domain names, office space, computers. It cost me money to go and work there even though I was a Project Manager!

1121206758087639042.text: They were making websites for every key intersection in town. One of my jobs was to painstakingly and very manually paint a beautiful version of the map of the intersection (what Google Maps eventually did). Our maps were so slow that we put a message to our users to just wait!pic.twitter.com/yXlps3TOz5

1116096440734928897.text:
Airbnb

The founders got inspired about the idea in 2007. At their 2nd soft launch in SXSW, they got *one* customer. After their 3rd launch at DNC, they got some traffic but it fell and as a startup they were dying. Then YC happened and they re-launched in 2009.

2 yr to launch

1116096439937929216.text:
Slack 

Stewart Butterfield and team were building a game called Glitch starting in 2009. It just didn't work out, but looking at the usefulness of their internal team chat collaboration tool, they decided to package and launch it in 2014. 

5 yr journey to launch!

1116096439141060608.text:
Uber

Garrett Camp got inspired after feeling the frustration of hailing a cab in SF around 2008. Keen continued observations + belief, seed funded himself with $250k, attracted Travis Kalanick as an adviser and then later on to become the CEO.

2 yrs from idea to SF launch

1116096438344114176.text:
Lyft

Logan Green got inspired after a trip in 2006 from observing people in Zimbabwe giving rides to others and started Zimride. The team decided to create a peer to peer mobile app called Lyft in 2012/2013 and sold Zimride to Enterprise. 

6 yrs journey to founding of Lyft!

1050985036999098368.text: The UX shouldn’t be where users are micro-managing each of their elevator rides, but instead only signal faster access intensity when they need it.

1050985034851610624.text: If the number of people in the building keeps increasing, a system based on the elevator grouping requests on adjacent floors would get overwhelmed. Tokens could serve as a charging filter, an access mechanism to resolve congestion in the marketplace.

1050985032729354242.text:
For people unwilling to spend sufficient tokens for travel in such an elevator, they end up with increased wait times, and being frustrated - not finding the system fair. 

But markets find their own efficiencies, just as the housing market does.

1050985030447595524.text: Thus, for emergency service professionals, folks having personal emergencies, couriers and others for whom time is more precious - market dynamics of such an elevator will ensure it prioritizes their requests

1050985027205390336.text: If the token represents speed of service fulfillment, then such an elevator going down from the 25th flr would skip Flr 15 above for the higher incentive from Flr 20 + From Flr 1

1050985024940437505.text:
For example:
- 3 users on Floor 15 each stake 10 tokens = 30 to go down to Flr 1
- 1 user on Floor 20 stakes 100 tokens to go down to Flr 1
- 2 users on Flr 1 stake 20 to go up to Flr 5

Airbnb right now is artificially constrained and focused on travel. But this brand has something magical.

Just as starting an e-commerce startup requires navigating around Amazon, a P2P market requires thinking around Airbnb.

Its a force of nature, and you plan around it.

1042532607185973248.text:
For such startups, if Airbnb also uses a public blockchain eventually + issues its own token — how will your product differentiate ? If it recognizes it is a *platform for P2P trust*, then what happens ? 

An Airbnb token could be the only token which matters for any P2P market.

1042532603897602048.text: For token based marketplaces which succeed to a given extent, a growth-hungry Airbnb could eventually co-opt the open source code *and* data, owning the consumer experience with its own brand for any legit P2P commerce.

1042532600756133888.text:
It can, and I believe it eventually will, extend into adjacent P2P marketplaces such as hiring a driver, dog walking, credit, compute capacity, disk space rental, etc.

Think Amazon, but 100x bigger. 

In a trustless world, people can trust each other through the Airbnb brand.

1038651314438201349.text:
UX eg 2: Psychological cost of token usage choices

Continuous decision making imposes a psychological cost on users. Consider Bittorrent vs Netflix -- the P2P service requires you to make a lot more choices, while the other abstracts it away

This is about end-end venture design

1038651312915664896.text:
UX eg 1: Financial cost

~500MM users in India pay $1-$2/mo for plans like 42GB @ 50Mbps

A popular dApp => network congestion => single txn fees > entire monthly wireless bill. That user, earning in INR (Rupee) also has to bet against USD and hope for +INR/-USD and +USD/-ETH

1038208391582179328.text:
RSS world pre-iPhone:
- Millions of websites published a feed (“tokens”)
- Dozens of feed readers popped up, optimizing on UI/UX & scalability (“wallets”)
- Millions of websites displayed these feed reader buttons (persistent free marketing for free products)

Users didn’t adopt.

1038107703548071936.text:
If this industry is successful few years from now with tens of MMs of users, I doubt if we will even be talking about crypto, tokens, or blockchains — it just needs to work behind the scenes, empowering a delightful product from user point of view.

Its time to re-calibrate.

1038107701312507904.text:
Thank you all for your efforts, but the next phase needs to be about re-thinking the UX at an industry-wide level

Let RSS be a good reminder of how an entire tech narrative can fail, and why solving tech problems is meaningless in of itself

This is distraction of local maxima.

1038107699056009217.text:
The idea has taken hold but the industry needs to reboot to think about the UX and “making what people want” — @paulg 

Truth, transparency, open data and incentivized, disintermediated systems are here to stay but we need to build delightful products which tens of millions love.

1038107694224134144.text:
The Crypto Era 1.0 which began in 2008 is now precariously placed as it too is user-work dependent

After a 10 yr span of massive capital, code and ideas deployment:

Top Tokens & dApps < 1000 users

Top Coins < 1MM users

while a random app like Sarahah reached ~100MM userspic.twitter.com/mxVoac0mKV

1038107687534309376.text:
We can call these “managed experiences”. 

The idea of aggregation was powerful, but of users individually doing “work” for it just didn’t take off. 

Downloading a plugin to make X work ? Heck, no!

1038107685336436738.text:
But the idea of news aggregation did win, just not in the form the industry anticipated back in 2005-2008. 

Facebook became the dominant personal news aggregator, to the point it got accused of being used to influence elections. Aggregators like Techmeme also found a good model

1038107681783861249.text: Turns out, it was an industry wide UX problem - it was asking users for too much: copy-paste RSS feeds in their favorite reader. But more importantly, despite the “obvious” hassle of going to diff websites for news, people were OK with that. The industry made what very few wantedpic.twitter.com/3SBGDe8pda

1038107672745103360.text: Yet, despite the products from innovative startups (Netvibes, etc) to tech titans (Google Reader), and almost every single website offering a RSS feed — the industry as a whole collapsed.

1038107670564155392.text: There was total conviction on the part of bloggers, journalists, VCs, founders, developers and others in the ecosystem that RSS “had to and would” go mainstream. Heck, there were around 35 feed readers before we launched ours (Alertle)

1038107668278210560.text:
I paid a massive personal price at the time - getting sucked up in the enthusiasm of the ecosystem. 

Opportunity cost at the time was invested in RSS which failed to take off. Not being in Silicon Valley further limited career opps.

There are strong parallels with crypto now

7/8 The biggest challenge is triggering the network effects. Most people gravitate towards the simplest + cheapest + most convenient option. 

An exchange traded token where current price is based on future projections makes it more expensive for current users= -ve network effect

1028874542934974464.text: 6/8 It can be argued that introduction of a simple language like English made the world a better place. So would a few of the said "fat protocols". And even as longer term their value gravitates towards 0, they provide interim returns to their investors. They need to be built.

1028874541827645440.text: 5/8 So if for a certain period of time ENG tokens were scarce and in use, the early holders of such tokens would have enjoyed some gains (this period was ~400 yrs) -- even though in the ultimate scenario, more popular the protocol, more the value of the token goes down to 0.

1028874540779073537.text: 4/8 With blockchains, since the data is openly available, any one "fat protocol" which does a great job at building network effects is by definition also enabling its would-be competitors. In this scenario, the cheapest token for continued usage wins eventually.

1028874539709550593.text: 3/8 There were costs associated with initial entry, as one had to learn it. But if there were costs associated with ongoing usage, then not only would its adoption have been much slower/smaller, it would have also been prone to being replaced with an interoperable language.

1028874538623201280.text: 2/8 The British Empire imposed English as the governance language in the areas it ruled, but when the Empire was kicked out, the freed countries continued using English as their primary governance language. Why ? The network effects were established + it was also free.

1026195880200818688.text: Everybody on Artemis earns and spends in slugs. Whether you are a delivery driver or a welder, you earn in slugs. People spend in slugs as well: rent a bed (eg 8000 slugs/month), or a bathroom, or buy a beer.

1026195879093514240.text: ".. Add it all together, and the cost per gram for getting something–a person or an object–landed on the moon can be calculated as an SLG. "https://www.fastcompany.com/40494297/70000-moon-vacations-the-interstellar-economics-of-andy-weirs-new-book-artemis …

1026195877986222080.text: Andy Weir calculated that 1 slug = 6 USD "..it ends up costing around $7,000 per person to go into low Earth orbit, and $35 per kilogram for freight. Add another $160 per kilogram to soft-land on the surface of the moon.

1026195873502519297.text: SLG: Soft landed grams ("slugs"). One slug gives the ability to get 1 gram of cargo transported from Earth to the Artemis lunar colony on proprietary (KSC) spaceships. Cargo is valued, thus ability to transport cargo is valued, and this is what all of Artemis wants.

1004962542752448512.text: 3. What is needed is a consumer-oriented blockchain which makes the trade-off for efficiency over decentralization. Users want transparency, but do not care where or how that data is stored as long as they get value from it.

1004962539392778240.text: 2. But Ethereum is not where consumer apps need to be running though. It adds cost and unnecessary overhead from a user perspective.
